fav_project: Covid 19 On economy of the nation was my favourite project I worked on in the news rooms where I was able to analyse using data from different districts how the pandemic affected businesses and revenue collection ands it's associated remedies to the food security in Acholi and northern Uganda at

fav_journalist: My friend, Attila Btorfy. He always inspires me to be better. He has very unique ideas and worldview regarding data visualisation, and it is very fun to work on projects with him.
fav_project: My latest project is always my favourite. It is a collaboration project with the City of Budapest, mapping the cultural network of the city, showing connections (by collaborations) of cultural places of the city. Check it out here: https://terkep.alternativbudapest.hu/index.html
field_improvement: Number of experts, freedom within newsrooms to create bigger projects taking a longer time, Number of schools, organisations teaching data visualisation to students

discipline_4: Arts and Humanities (e.g. journalism, linguistics, history)
occupation: Other (Please specify):MA Digital Journalism, undertaking a project on Data Journalism in Kenya in coverage of health, focusing on COVID-19
formation_5: NA
formation_8: Other (Please specify):Self-teaching- am yet to be an expert
type_dj_1: I write stories that are enriched and supported by data
work_task_9: Other (Please specify):At infant stages as this is self-teaching
tools_15: Other (Please specify):Adobe Illustrator, InDesign and Photoshop-Excel in some instances as it works with Illustrator
skill_training_9: None / Other (Please specify):Self-teaching on Data Visualization
beat_19: Other (Please specify):Am a Communications Officer in a human rights organisation, with affiliation to a women journalism mentorship organisation-The Woman's Newsroom Foundation
medium_1: Online platforms of broadcast or print media outlets
dedicated_unit: Other (Please specify):No dedicated unit on data; self-interest has led me to identify stories which can be told better by illustration, than prose.
technology_harness_7: Software that facilitates data analysis and visualisation
barriers_2: Lack of time for training and deepening knowledge of specific skills
barriers_7: Other (Please specify):Data journalism is taking baby steps and most leading media houses have not fully embraced it; and may not be ready to invest in it. Most journalists I have interacted with 'fear' data as a mathematics/science thing that is hard. This also shows misconceptions among journalists about what data journalism entails. Also, mostly event-based journalism amidst tight deadlines may be denying budding journalists the time to be analytical for impact reporting. Press conferences and statements are the news instead of being sparks of the real story- this is a personal evaluation and based on what am encountering as I research on data journalism in Kenya.
data_j_value_4: It makes a story more reliable
data_j_value_5: It is necessary given the increase of data
data_j_value_7: It helps readers make sense of what they are reading
pandemic_workmode: Other (Please specify):Class moved fully virtual. Working has been hybrid- with more time at the office.
pandemic_project: Other (Please specify):Yes but not on data specifically- since am in corporate communications.
pandemic_workload: Other (Please specify):Substantially increased- But not on data journalism- as before, am not in mainstream journalism
pandemic_time_pressure: Other (Please specify):Substantially increased- But not on data journalism- as before, am not in mainstream journalism
pandemic_impact_2: It has strengthened data journalism as a field
fav_journalist: Marcelo Soares- He was skeptical of government data and his collections and collation of data in 2020 helped many make informed decisions in Brazil, including the government which had to rework its data collection strategy amidst denial of COVID-19. Even media houses relied on his data. Astounding!
field_improvement: Visualisation, analysis- If i can learn the entire package, the better.

discipline_4: Arts and Humanities (e.g. journalism, linguistics, history)
occupation: Other (Please specify):Full time editor/reporter, but i work often with data journalists but am not the main perpetrator in most projects
formation_5: Self-taught using online resources (videos, blogs, forums)
graphic_tools: Mostly external software but some in-house
beat_19: Other (Please specify):Financial services, specifically mutual fund regulation and governance
medium_1: Online platforms of broadcast or print media outlets
dedicated_unit: Other (Please specify):Intermittent. Wide recognition that many stories can only be explored in the data that outlines the situation; management has hired a number of early career reporters with DJ training, but makes no accommodation for specific projects and provides few tools or resources. Current company is relatively small, but a previous gig at S&P Global was similar. Lots of DJs on staff, but they mostly did graphics to go along with stories reported and written using traditional data sources (earnings reports, etc). S&P owns two analyst firms that produce high volumes of high quality data on the performance of certain markets, but the news division is mostly stuck using data from earnings reports and public statements as graphic additions to a text story, or using reports from the analyst firms about projects they develop for paying customers. Very little enterprise reporting focused primarily on data sources to define or corroborate details of the event.
collaboration_type_1: One-time project and separate content production
collaboration_opportunities_5: Outcome is better than possible alone
collaboration_opportunities_7: Other (Please specify):Access to proprietary data that is accurate and methodologically sound, but is angled due to the commercial concerns driving business decisions, on commercial questions of interest to the analyst-firm's immediate customers rather than the broader population of readers for which the news division tries to write.
challenges_producing_more_4: Lack of adequate knowledge in data visualisation
challenges_producing_more_5: Lack of adequate software for scraping or analysis
challenges_producing_more_6: Lack of adequate software for data visualisation
technology_harness_7: Software that facilitates data analysis and visualisation
technology_harness_11: Other (Please specify):most of those, as discrete topics, are irrelevant to data journalism (drones are great at photography, not so great at large-scale surveys of melting polar ice. "Programming languages" definitely qualifies as important, but is only one tiny step more specific than saying computers will be important, so that data point won't be terribly useful. Python vs R vs ML development tools/languages would probably be more relevant.)). NLP and NLG are aspects of machine learning, which is a more efficient set of methods to identify patterns. software to generate language or stories automatically is not that useful to the reporting process, but could make generation of stock and sports performance tables faster and easier. 5G is a networking technology that is only suited to carry information, not gather it, unless you're researching the process of development and spread of 5G (which is common and highly justified). Blockchain is also a communications/security protocol, although understanding how it works is critical to anyone trying to cover anything having to do with cryptocurrencies or the effort to develop distributed finance networks.
barriers_2: Lack of time for training and deepening knowledge of specific skills
barriers_7: Other (Please specify):Perception among those without DJ training that data journalism requires a set of skills that are abstruse and so technical they're almost impossible to acquire for anyone who has left school or is more inclined toward words than numbers. DJs need more examples of and assistance from people focused on doing the reporting and getting the stories, who may not be able to do any more with statistical analysis than understand an election result, but are willing to enlist the quant skills of those who are good with analytics and data management. that means understanding a lot about what the data is or represents and what situations it may describe, but not necessarily the need to program in R. DJ is a really good stick, but traditional journalists aren't well trained in how to use it to hit a target they can find but not subdue. DJs have a good hold on the stick, but don't always know how to figure appropriate targets, what to hit on a particular target and when it's appropriate to start swinging.
data_j_value_4: It makes a story more reliable
data_j_value_5: It is necessary given the increase of data
data_j_value_7: NA
data_j_value_9: Other (Please specify):multiply "it is necessary given the increase of data" by several orders of magnitude
pandemic_workmode: It has not affected my working mode
pandemic_resources: Other (Please specify):It made working with colleagues more awkward, made many sources easier to reach (electronically), but had very little or no impact on the resources available to the newsroom except in business-development projects whose details and result were generally invisible to those gathering news rather than figuring out new formats and networks on which to tweet it.
pandemic_workload: None of the above
pandemic_time_pressure: Other (Please specify):Time pressure is a result of changes in organizational efforts or priorities on the business side, not an increase or significant redirection of workload.
pandemic_skills_8: Not applicable / Other (Please specify):My hands-on skills didn't improve much, but I got a lot more opportunities than usual to explain how data and the analysis thereof is supposed to work and the difference between government-published data, data that must be disclosed by public corporations and the vast amounts of behavioral and purchasing/economic data that are often inaccessible to journalists except when they are collected and revealed by whistleblowers with internal access (as in the Facebook stories earlier this year).
field_improvement: Its ability to cover controversy fairly, while also communicating a sense of scale and priority to reduce the impact of trolls using lies or irrelevancies to radicalize the willfully ignorant.

barriers_7: Other (Please specify):Elaboration on struggle to enter industry: lack of early-career opportunities, many people only advertise for experienced hires, but it's a chicken-egg problem. Also, the opportunities are almost always in the global north and Western countries. It's hard to get proper training and reputational recognition if you're coming from elsewhere.

pandemic_impact_1: It has increased audience data literacy
pandemic_impact_7: None / Other (Please specify):It increases public exposure to the presence of data in their news and increases appreciation for reliable and timely data, but I'm not sure we can assume it increases data literacy per se. I think basic statistical fallacies and poor data viz practices are still prevalent in the public and in newsrooms. But there's more appetite from newsrooms and corporates for data viz and data storytelling.
field_improvement: More systematic support for journalists outside of North America and Europefunding, mentorship, visa sponsorship, etc.
